comments.commentBody: No, not really. Luck has nothing to do with this.

I only fault President Obama on the economic front for one thing; not insisting that the stimulus of 2009 have a jobs bill in it to fix our crumbling infrastructure.  He took office in January 2009 facing the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression and instant obstructionism by the minority in the United States Senate.  In the Great Depression, home prices did not recover until the early 1950's and that was with the great economic stimulus of World War II.

So what are you suggesting? We have just begun to explore the possibilities of wind and solar. I am all for these alternatives to become the norm. Aside from the physical aspects, ie, wind turbines destroying the view of the countryside, fields upon fields of solar arrays taking the place of crops, I have to agree that these renewable alternatives are the answer. But now we are faced with the not-in-my-backyard syndrome.

Yes, it boggles the mind to think how close we came to absolute disaster by having Al Gore as President! I thank God everyday that he lost and that we still have some hope for a future for our country. But you shouldn't be too sad, you got Obama. In some ways he is worse than "Mr-Inconveniently-Ignores-the-Truth". Now we just need to vote him out and get someone in there who can get our country back on track and moving again, away from this Socialist Utopia modeled after Greece (and we see how well that is working).

Do I want to destroy the environment? Of course not. Am I looking for ways to breathe dirty air, drink crummy water and cover the land with parking lots. No. But we must remember that this earth was created for us, for our use, and with proper stewardship, we can take care of it and benefit from it at the same time. But forcing everyone to go a certain direction because of nonexistent and unfounded pipe-dreams (Solyndra) will just waste our precious financial resources and get us deeper in debt. At the same time it will cause severe harm to so many (like this story shows) and ruin everyone's future.

If you like the Socialist ideals of France and Greece, you are certainly welcome to move there and enjoy their bliss. Otherwise, please leave our free country Free. Vote for responsible, reality based leaders who can get us back on track, following the constitution created by our beloved founding fathers who had experienced first hand the trials of tyranny.

I cry to think of how different our world, and country could be, if Al Gore had not been robbed of the Presidency by the Supreme Court.  I  try to imagine if we had chosen to spend our war dollars on energy independence, by adequately funding wind and solar and conservation and automotive technology.  Clean jobs galore.  And a clean environment.  It boggles my mind, that one person's vote kept us from that possibility.

Don't you e-mail or Twitter interesting things you see on the web to your friends, AF? The Scuttlebot is our collection of things on the Web that we found fascinating and that we wanted to share with our readers, like you. There are a lot of interesting reports out there and we found that highlighting some of it is a delight to our readers. How is that low?
The Zuckerberg "story" may represent a new low for the NYTimes: quoting an LA Times 'reporter' who had to go to Google to find out if she really had a story (she didn't).

To clarify: My electronics were used in the first version of the project. The current version as shown in the article uses a different CPU and camera (and possibly network interface, I'm not sure). The current internals were developed by Bran Sorem, I just got the ball rolling.

As part of my work a few years ago, I compared, by state, the percentage of adults with college degrees to the bachelor's degrees awarded by public and private colleges in the state (measured as a percentage of the state's population).

The correlation was essentially zero. As examples, New Jersey was a bottom 10 state in the number of bachelor's degrees its colleges awarded, while ranking in the top 10 for adults with bachelor degrees. Indiana, on the other hand, with three large world-class universities (Indiana, Purdue and Notre Dame) was a top producer of bachelor's degrees, but a bottom 5 state in adults with college degrees.

Three reasons:

First, jobs. Graduating more engineers in Dayton will not result in more engineering jobs in Dayton. It's much easier for engineering firms to lure students from Dayton (and elsewhere) to their cities, then relocate their operation to Dayton.

Second, location, location, location. Cities like SF, NYC, Chicago, Seattle, the Twin Cities, etc. have the cache and culture (and, in some cases, the weather) to attract young college graduates. The NYC spillover can be seen in New Jersey. Dayton, not so much.

Third, college graduates cannot be frozen or otherwise stored, only to be released when jobs arrive. They are people, not oil.
I love the Republican response to lowing the cost of healthcare, "Go shopping."  You are right, you don't have time to go shopping.
Can you imagine what it is going to like to compare insurance coverages and read those policies?  What a joke insurance coverage is...
You are probably on plan B-2 / Z-28 -001-NO.   Now if  you would have signed up for plan C-1 / X-28-002-YE, you might have been covered unless it was an emergency or just preventive care.
And guess what, it is only going to get worse.  I don't blame the president or any new healthcare bill, it is just the system.  I wish we could use veterinarians.
What a racket!

"This country is failing on multiple levels; at some point, one has to look at the much more humane and graceful social market economies of Canada, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Japan, New Zealand and Australia and conclude that America is a failed experiment gone greedy, unfeeling and sociopathic."

So Socrates, are you planning to move?

The only way to reverse the hijacking of the Moneyed States of America is to storm the Washington, D.C cockpit and commandeer the controls from our bribed representatives.

The Occupy movement has it right and we need to metastasize it so that all corporations and representatives fear the citizenry, not exploit them for every last cent.

Market capitalism should always be heavily regulated; unregulated capitalism is a vicious bloodthirsty vulture designed for the sociopathic.

This country is failing on multiple levels; at some point, one has to look at the much more humane and graceful social market economies of Canada, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Japan, New Zealand and Australia and conclude that America is a failed experiment gone greedy, unfeeling and sociopathic.

What does America stand for ?

The answer is not pretty.

And what is the alternative? Become a plumber, electrician, car manufacturer, chef, shop foreman? Most people going to college have interests, goals and pursuits that can only be fulfilled through a college education of some sort. And then there is social prestige, ego, pride, etc.

I'm willing to be that you are or will be telling your children to get a college degree, so lets see how far your skepticism goes.

Older industrial cities like Dayton have much worse problems than a lack of college graduates. I'm thinking of poor weather, decaying housing stock, and a terrible economy. Glorifying college or its graduates won't make it a better or more attractive city. And this is coming from an (unemployed) lawyer, so it's not as if I were resentful of the highly educated. Rather, I am skeptical of the value of higher education in general.

I suspect there are some serious correlation/causation issues that were unexamined by the author and editors of this article. Dayton and Charlotte are very different cities in many ways, and I doubt that Dayton can use Charlotte's success as a blueprint for its future efforts.
oh rats.  why don't you run around the lake?
The problem with anecdotal evidence, which people commonly cite in response to articles like this, is that it proves nothing and is, in fact, irrelevant.

I run a lot after my bypass surgery. I guess time will tell but I am aware that my plaque is reversing, likely based more on my diet than exercise.

My plaque is reversing less than a year after my quadruple bypass surgery. 

I take 10mg of Crestor a day.  Maybe that is the cause of the Plaque reversal?  Maybe it is the baby aspirin?  Maybe it is the 30 mile run I ran on Sunday?  Maybe its the aluminium foil hat I made myself to avoid cosmic radiation…

My latest carotid artery test: http://wholefed.org/2012/05/03/reversing-plaque-maybe-its-the-aluminium-...

Ian Welch
www.wholefed.org

You have to be very careful when interpreting studies that look at risk factors rather than at outcomes, like strokes or heart attacks, directly. For example, say I have a patient dying of an infection who has a high fever. I would like to test whether tylenol will fix his infection. I give him some tylenol, and his fever goes away, but he dies soon afterward. My study would have two very different outcomes depending on whether I used fever or death at my outcome of choice. If we chose fever as the outcome, then the tylenol successfully "cured" the patient, as the fever went away. If we chose death as the outcome, then the opposite is true.

In the same way, this study has shown that there is at least a transient change in parameters in some patients. What is the significance of this in terms of clinical outcomes like stroke or heart attack? We don't know as this was not investigated. It could very well be that the groups are identical and this represents a fluke. Alternatively, perhaps these researchers have identified an interesting new aspect of the physiological response to exercise worthy of further follow up.

For now, I'd sum it up as this: they have looked at a relatively small group of people (the standard for cardiac studies is tens of thousands of patients) and made an extremely provocative conclusion. The onus is now on the research community to confirm, repeat, and expand on this experiment. I certainly won't be changing my own exercise patterns any time soon.

One cannot escape their genetic make up. Different people can eat and diet differently with different results.

The same exercise too may have different physiological outcomes in different people, depending on diets and genes.

Each one of us has to work out our own regimes. If you are doing it right, you FEEL it and know it. Ignore what others "think" or say.
Eat the right food in one portion servings....not as much as you want!!

Prior to my surgery last year, almost to the day…. I was under the impression that as long as I balanced the good with the bad I would be fine.  If I ate 20 chicken wings and a pitcher of beer for dinner I would go for a long run the next day.  If I ate a big steak I would make sure I had a huge salad.  The problem is that this approach does not work.  If it did then my weight would not have gone from 200 to 235 pds in 5 years.

Let me put it this way.  You cannot exercise your way out of chronic disease.  Unless you are Michael Phelps, burning 10,000 calories a day, you will not be able to exercise off the calories you take in.  To really lose weight and reach your ideal body size you have to eat the right foods.  By eliminating Dairy & Animal Protein and avoiding Oil, you can drastically reduce the amount of fat you take in.

The point is eat the right stuff, then exercise.  You will be amazed by the results.

“The most powerful determinant of your dietary intake is your energy expenditure,” says Steven Gortmaker, who heads Harvard’s Prevention Research Center on Nutrition and Physical Activity. “If you’re more physically active, you’re going to get hungry and more."

John Cloud had a great article in Time Magazine a few years ago, Why Exercise Won’t Make You Thin.

Full post: http://wholefed.org/2012/03/14/the-good-stuff-you-do-cant-outrun-the-bad...

Ian Welch
www.wholefed.org

Indians are very fortunate in that they are treated with understanding and empathy by the West. Take for example the recent NYT article "India’s Economy Slows, With Global Implications" by Yardley. Compare its gentle tone with the consistently partisan treatment of another NYT correspondent Wong on China and you see what I mean.

India will overcome its difficulties by its own bootstrap. Just don't waste energies on becoming someone's "counterweight" to China. Good luck to all your hard work and resilience, India!
